data.title: SurfaceTool isn't applying textures to certain primitives when generating a mesh.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
MacOSX : Darwin Kernel Version 16.0.0: Mon Aug 29 17:56:20 PDT 2016; root:xnu-3789.1.32~3/RELEASE_X86_64 x86_64

Also confirmed not working on my Linux box; Debian 7.

Godot 2.1  ( Downloaded via Steam ) 

**Issue description** 
It seems that when using SurfaceTool to generate a mesh, textures can't be applied to TRIANGLE_STRIP or TRIANGLE_FAN (possibly others).  It does apply to TRIANGLES though.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1.  Create a scene laid out like so: 

```
[Node]
  \- Camera
  \- Light Source
  \- MeshInstance
```

Add a script to the MeshInstance for generating a mesh via surface tool.  Try applying a texture to a triangle strip or fan. 

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):

PRIMIVIVE_TRIANGLES script below is based on this: http://www.gamefromscratch.com/post/2015/09/25/Godot-Engine-Tutorial-Part-15-Static-and-Programmatic-3D-Meshes.aspx

```
extends MeshInstance

func _ready():
  var surfTool = SurfaceTool.new()
  var mesh = Mesh.new()
  var material = FixedMaterial.new()
  material.set_parameter(material.PARAM_DIFFUSE,Color(1,0,0,1))

  surfTool.set_material(material)
  surfTool.begin(VS.PRIMITIVE_TRIANGLES)

  surfTool.add_uv(Vector2(0,0))
  surfTool.add_vertex(Vector3(0,0,0))

  surfTool.add_uv(Vector2(0,1))
  surfTool.add_vertex(Vector3(0,5,0))

  surfTool.add_uv(Vector2(1,1))
  surfTool.add_vertex(Vector3(5,5,0))

  surfTool.generate_normals()
  surfTool.index()
  surfTool.commit(mesh)

  self.set_mesh(mesh)
```

The texture is properly applied to the triangle, but if you try to generate other primitives, such as triangle strips, you just get a pure black mesh.

PRIMITIVE_TRIANGLE_STRIPS : 

```
extends MeshInstance

func _ready():
  var surfTool = SurfaceTool.new()
  var mesh = Mesh.new()
  var material = FixedMaterial.new()
  material.set_parameter(material.PARAM_DIFFUSE,Color(1,0,0,1))

  surfTool.set_material(material)
  surfTool.begin(VS.PRIMITIVE_TRIANGLE_STRIP)

  surfTool.add_uv(Vector2(0,0))
  surfTool.add_vertex(Vector3(0,0,0))

  surfTool.add_uv(Vector2(0,1))
  surfTool.add_vertex(Vector3(0,5,0))

  surfTool.add_uv(Vector2(1,0))
  surfTool.add_vertex(Vector3(5,0,0))

  surfTool.add_uv(Vector2(1,1))
  surfTool.add_vertex(Vector3(5,5,0))

  surfTool.generate_normals()
  surfTool.index()

  surfTool.commit(mesh)

  self.set_mesh(mesh)
```

data.title: Any way to set the background of a 2D viewport?
data.body:
I am trying to use a Viewport in 2D, but I failed so far at setting its background to a solid color.

I tried this so far:

``` gdscript
    var world = World.new()
    var env = Environment.new()
    env.set_background(Environment.BG_COLOR)
    env.set_background_param(Environment.BG_PARAM_COLOR, Color(0,0,0))
    world.set_environment(env)
    viewport.set_world(world)
    viewport.set_use_own_world(true)
```

But it has no effect in 2D. It just uses the default background color...

Is this feature available in Godot? Or not exposed? Or a bug?

Edit: quick note, my use case involves rendering to a texture, in case detail matters

data.title: RayCast2D appears to use previously collided item
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
x11.64 - v2.2.alpha 

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When I change raycast position and cast_to, and stores the next item, it appears to print the previous item's name before the new item.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Download example code:
[RayCast2D Bug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/539453/RayCast2D.Bug.zip)

Run program;
- Click on Item#1 (nothing prints out)
- Click on Item#1 again (Item#1 name prints out)
- Click on Item#2 (name for Item#1 prints out)
- Click on Item#2 (name for Item#2 prints out)

As you can see, even after setting new positions and cast_to, it keeps displaying previous item after changing.

data.title: Add more scripts and features for audio
data.body:
Unfortunately, in the current state of Godot Engine are very few tools to work with audio via scripts. Why not add a function like the following:
- **retrieve_bpm_from_music** - automatic analysis of the audio to give the approximate value of BPM.
- **get_volume** - getting the audio volume in the current frame.
- **get_rms** - getting more "soft" audio volume value in the current frame
- **and other...**
## What is this for?

For example, I need to animate the mouth of the character based on a sample of his voice. The RMS value would help me to do this automatically through scripts. Or make a graphic equalizer which would have demonstrated the noise level around the character. In an extreme case, it opens up at least some space for creation of rhythm games and games based on music files.

I know that usually respond to such requests, "write your own plug-in", but:
- I do not know how to write plug-ins;
- My friend, who understands the C language, says that writing such a plugin is problematic;
- Such basic things should be in engine by defalt, such as a Construct Classic or Unity (which paid, non-optimized and hard-to-learn, meh!);

data.title: fragment shader : DISCARD does not work as expected
Ability to access editor 3d camera in tool mode
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I haven't found any way to access 3d editor camera from tool mode. It could be very helpful, for example if I would like to write a custom plugin that would allow to select object by clicking on them in 3d view. 
I guess proper function should be added to EditorPlugin.

data.title: Ability to produce geometry or passes from shaders/materials?
data.body:
Maybe the title is not clear enough, but I'll explain:

Multi-pass:
Coming from Unity, I saw it's possible to tell an object to render twice or more only from its shader. For example, it allows to implement 3D outlines easily (draw mesh a second time, but extrude along normals, reverse normals and put it on an opaque pass), perform fur shading by duplicating layers of geometry in parts needing that, or implementing other cool effects that cannot be done in another way.
In Godot, shaders don't go beyond being shaders in the strict term of it. They cannot tell how many passes it has to be rendered properly. Because of that, the node must be duplicated (and then processed twice), or a script has to be added, a self-contained material is not enough. Could such capability be considered in the future?

Geometry generation:
Going a bit further, possibly different area. I know it's possible today to generate geometry from shaders, and so not being forced to do it on the CPU, client-side towards the graphic card. For example, send a low-poly terrain on the graphic card, and subdivide it dynamically on the GPU (is tesselation the right word?). I know this is a fairly advanced topic and might not be supported by some graphic cards, but would it be possible to use it in Godot in the future?

data.title: feature request: ability of selecting sub-scenes from the main 3D view
data.body: complex 3D levels may be a pain to edit, if you can't select each elements from the 3d view, you have to find each scene element by browsing the hierarchy tree and, if you have hundred of elements made by sub-scenes, it's very frustrating finding a specific one.

data.title: Delay parameter of `Tween.interpolate_property` seems to be ignored in tween sequences
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
This issue applies to https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/6613 commit

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Let's say I have this simple function to  move object to some target position, and then return to it's previous position. Let's say I'm doing this with tween by starting two tweens (one of them is starting with delay)
here is the code:

```
func tweenToAndReturn(inTargetPos):
    var modelCurrentPos = object.get_translation();
    tween.interpolate_property(object, "transform/translation", modelCurrentPos, inTargetPos,0.3, Tween.TRANS_QUAD, Tween.EASE_IN);
    tween.interpolate_property(object, "transform/translation", inTargetPos, modelCurrentPos,0.3, Tween.TRANS_QUAD, Tween.EASE_OUT,0.3);
    tween.start();
```

Here is how it works before #6613  (or with #6613 but also with  #6863) 
![tween-sequence-1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/19494768/e112192c-9580-11e6-8440-58daab39f53d.gif)

Here is how it works with #6613
![tween-sequence-2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6129594/19494799/05cdd7ba-9581-11e6-8007-21a09722184a.gif)

I'm not sure what's happening exactly, but first thought is that delay parameter of `interpolate_property` is for some reason ignored in #6613 (or this interpolation is already killed at the time it need to start)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Check sample project without  #6613 testCube will be able to return to it's initial position
2. Apply #6613 testCube won't be able to return to it's initial position

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[TweenSequenceAndDelay.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/537269/TweenSequenceAndDelay.zip)

data.title: Missing return statement inside tween logic
data.body:
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/pull/6613/  commit broke backward compatibility for my project, 
It turned out that missing 'return' statement from line 833 affects the logic of tween

data.title: Fix Keyboard Input Hangs when using modifiers
data.body:
`InputMap::event_is_action` now ignores keyboard modifiers if the event is not pressed.
Clarify difference between `InputMap::action_has_event` and `InputMap::event_is_action` in docs.

E.g.

```
# Action Map
print("Action Map")
InputMap.add_action("a")
InputMap.add_action("shift_a")
var action_ev = InputEvent()
action_ev.type = InputEvent.KEY
action_ev.scancode = KEY_A

InputMap.action_add_event("a", action_ev)
printt("a", var2str(action_ev))

action_ev.shift = true
InputMap.action_add_event("shift_a", action_ev)
printt("shift_a", var2str(action_ev))

# Key test
var ev = InputEvent()
ev.type = InputEvent.KEY
ev.scancode = KEY_A
ev.shift = true

print("\n")
printt("Event", var2str(ev))
printt("Released", "has_event", "is_action")
printt( "regular", InputMap.action_has_event("a", ev), InputMap.event_is_action(ev, "a") ) # False, True
printt( "shifted", InputMap.action_has_event("shift_a", ev), InputMap.event_is_action(ev, "shift_a") ) # True, True

print("\n")
printt("Pressed", "has_event", "is_action")
ev.pressed = true
printt( "regular", InputMap.action_has_event("a", ev), InputMap.event_is_action(ev, "a") ) # False, False
printt( "shifted", InputMap.action_has_event("shift_a", ev), InputMap.event_is_action(ev, "shift_a") ) # True, True
```

Closes #6388.

data.title: More constructors for Vectors
data.body:
Currently, it is pretty long to make a Vector3 out of a Vector2:

``` gdscript
Vector3(vec2.x, vec2.y, 0)
```

Same goes for vice-versa:

``` gdscript
Vector2(vec3.x, vec3.y)
```

Now, imagine that the said Vector3/Vector2 has a very long name.. It would quickly become unmanageble, right? :smile: 

---

That's why, I would like to propose (after a quick discussion with @karroffel and @reduz) a few utility constructors, similar to the shading language (which should be non-implicit, to minimize bugs):

``` gdscript
func Vector3(Vector2 xy, float z = 0):
func Vector3(float x = 0, Vector2 yz):
func Vector2(Vector3 xy):
```

Now, the only few issues with this is that you can't:
1. Make `Vector3(v2.y, v2.x, 0)`, for example
2. Make `Vector2(v3.z, v3.x)`, which might need swizzling to work properly.

Anyway, what do you think of the proposed constructors? And also, do you think swizzling (`v3.xz`) is useful enough to include in GDScript?

data.title: RichTextLabel: Added get_visible_line_count method
data.body:
Also exposed get_line_count to GDScript.

The inner-workings of RichTextLabel is quite involved, and the simpled way of counting visible lines I could think of was this: for each line, increment visible line counter whenever there is something visible on that line. I made use of the existing visibility tests during PROCESS_DRAW, so a proper counting will happen only during draw cycle. But I guess this is OK, since when the widget is non-visible, visible line count is zero anyway.

data.title: SCons: Use colored output if available, change "colored"->"verbose"
data.body: Detect whether GCC supports colored output and use it.

data.title: Disable asserts in release mode
data.body:
Generated code should be smaller and faster.

This patch is extracted from old WebM PR.

Btw. in Godot `CFLAGS` works for C compiler, but `CCFLAGS` works for both C and C++ compilers on my computer. Description in `SConstruct` file tells that `CCFLAGS` is only for C++ compiler.

data.title: Better path follow
data.body:
This is a breaking change idea/suggestion/request:

PathFollow is a great tool but it requires to cut branches and reparenting poor children just to follow a path for awhile.

I was messing around in GDScript and nodes trying some approaches to see how could it be more flexible and got 2 ideas:
- One is that PathFollow can have a list of follower nodes from the scene and each member assigned an offset too.

![pathfollowers](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10215987/19450001/1cf1090c-947e-11e6-90e7-c1f6917de8ea.gif)

That way, a single pathfollow can move N nodes without altering the scene tree, allowing add and remove easily from following a path, even push nodes in a trail.
- The other idea that was thinking is make the PathFollow a parasite.

![brainslug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10215987/19450172/c131be58-947e-11e6-804e-390a0c2a9f38.png)

If a pathfollow is added as child of a node and assigned to a path in the scene (like a ParticleAttractor to an Emitter), it will move the parent along the path, this way could be more flexible than the other but harder to make a trail of nodes.
- Another not so breaking option could be that depending on who is the parent of PathFollow it could behave as now ( _or as the first idea which is a breaking one_ ) or with the second mode (if parent is not a path).

ps: I'm still bad with plugins so don't know if can be just done with that while keeping a simple/transparent way to use (the second idea sounds possible).

data.title: Isolate XAudio2 driver
data.body:
Now it's possible to compile for Windows platform if wanted. It's
supported only for Windows 8 or later, so it's not enabled by default.

data.title: Alterable playback speed for StreamPlayer
data.body:
Hi all-
I don't know if this is a big request on the programming level (although from what little I know of sound playback it _seems_ like it would just be a matter of increasing the playhead increment step), but I'd like to request the ability to put in a speed modifier to the StreamPlayer node. In many games, a subtle change of speed in the music can change the feel of the game. For example, someone making a Tetris game might want to speed up the music slightly when the block fall speed increases, or a platformer may want to increase speed when time starts running low, or a boss battle might want its music sped up when its health is down. Currently these effects can be emulated by actually creating different audio streams at different speeds, but this seems like a somewhat less than optimal solution (it takes time and adds more files to the project).

I wasn't sure if this was planned already, but I hadn't seen anything saying it was. So I figured I may as well put the request out there. Thanks!

data.title: RegEx Revamp Ideas
data.body:
I have been mulling over converting the regex library into a module in IRC, and I thought it would be a good opportunity to add to the library, one of which is going to break backwards compatibility. What do you think of them? Any ideas you'd like to add / modify to this?
### Results in a separate object

Previously, the results would be stored as a mutable variable in the expression object. I don't think it's a good principle to have a constant function `ex.find()` to affect the state of `ex`. I originally did this because that was how it was done and I was worried about backwards compatibility. What I propose is to instead return a separate object called RegExMatch, similar to [Python](https://docs.python.org/3/library/re.html):

Current:

```
var ex = RegEx.new()
ex.compile("Name: (\\w+)")
if ex.find("ID: 003\nName: John Doe"):
    print(ex.get_capture(1))
    print(ex.get_capture_start(1))
```

New (Proposed):

```
var ex = RegEx.new()
ex.compile("Name: (\\w+)")
var match = ex.match("ID: 003\nName: John Doe")
if match != null:
    print(match.get_group(1))
    print(match.get_pos(1))
```
### RegEx as a resource file

One annoyance I've had making use of the RegEx class is writing escapes because I have to escape the string before I can escape the expression, e.g. "\w" -> \w or worse "\\" -> \. Furthermore, the lack of access to constructors in the script means if you want to use them as a class member, it has to be compiled separately:

```
var re_string = RegEx.new()
var re_comments = RegEx.new()
# Some code
func _init():
    re_string.compile("\"([^\"]|\\\\.)*\"")
    re_comments.compile("#.*")
# Some more code
func _input(delta):
    # Actually use re_string and re_comments
    pass
```

One way to fix all this is to make it a resource class instead, where you can edit it in the properties window, save it as a file, and load it separately, like:

```
var re_string = load("res://regex/string.tres")
func _input(event):
    # With resource caching, it should only be loaded once
    var re_string2 = load("res://regex/string.tres")
    # The old method should still work
    var re_comments = RegEx.new()
    re_comments.compile("#.*")
```
### Other ideas

By integrating more closely with Godot, it should now be possible to add:
- Substitution
- Named groups

data.title: Documentation for group methods needed
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** All (docs)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Some important details about methods pertaining to groups are missing from the docs. There are no descriptions for _any_ SceneTree methods, including several pertaining to groups, and there's no info about add_to_group()'s second argument. There have been a couple questions on the Q&A about them, but they have gone unanswered. I'm particularly interested in:

SceneTree.call_group() - "int flags". There's a list of flags, but what do they do?

Node.add_to_group() - "persistent". It defaults to "false" which is confusing by itself, since nodes seem to "persist" in groups until removed.

data.title: Support for [ctrl] + [alt] + special character == [Alt Gr] + special character
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:** Windows & non-english keyboard layout - All versions

**Issue description:** When not using english keyboard, writing special chars like '>' and '<' (and many more) must be done with shortcut (right) <kbd>Alt Gr</kbd> + <kbd><</kbd>. Thats normal and fine, but on windows, lots of folks (like me) are used to (left) <kbd>ctrl</kbd> + (left)<kbd>alt</kbd> + <kbd><</kbd> which does not work and is very annoying (you know, you are used to _type_ code one way for 8+ years and then, this one editor does not support it).

Source: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AltGr_key#Control_.2B_Alt_as_a_substitute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AltGr_key#Control_.2B_Alt_as_a_substitute)

**Steps to reproduce:** 
set non english keyboard (czech in my case)
Godot -> script editor
<kbd>Alt gr</kbd> + <kbd>></kbd> = '>'
<kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>Alt</kbd> + <kbd>></kbd> = ''

Every native windows app (eh, native... even GIMP support this):
<kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>Alt</kbd> + <kbd>></kbd> = '>'

data.title: SCsub: Add python shebang as a hint for syntax highlighting
data.body:
It's a Unix shebang but I know at least from @vnen that it works as a hint for python syntax highlighting in Notepad++ on Windows.

Works fine for syntax highlighting in Kate and nano.

data.title: Build iPhone target failed after updating to Xcode 8
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
macOS Sierra, Godot 2.1 stable, Xcode 8

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
After updating to Xcode 8, build iPhone target failed with the following message:

> clang: warning: libstdc++ is deprecated; move to libc++ with a minimum deployment target of iOS 7
> ld: library not found for -lcrt1.3.1.o
> clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
> scons: **\* [bin/godot.iphone.opt.arm] Error 1
> scons: building terminated because of errors.

With Xcode 7, everything is just fine.
Going back to Xcode 7 by Time Machine, build OK as before!

**Steps to reproduce:**
Terminal build instruction is as the following:
Scons platform=iphone tools=no bits=64 target=release

Thanks for helping!

data.title: Correct #6530 Issue on unintended editor input after game crashes.
data.body: Grabbed focus from the editor in popup() when user press play, so no unintended inputs will affect the editor after a game crashes.
